From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia


2022 film by Kyra Sedgwick
This article is about the 2022 film. For other, see Space Oddity (disambiguation).


Space OddityTheatrical release posterDirected byKyra SedgwickWritten byRebecca BannerProduced by
Richard Arlook
Jack Greenbaum
Mark Maxey
Mickey Schiff
Kyra Sedgwick
Meredith Bagby
Valerie Stadler
Starring
Kyle Allen
Alexandra Shipp
Madeline Brewer
Carrie Preston
Simon Helberg
Kevin Bacon
CinematographyAlar KiviloEdited byStefanie VisserMusic by
Travis Bacon
Scott Hedrick
ProductioncompanyBig Swing ProductionsDistributed bySamuel Goldwyn FilmsRelease dates
June 12, 2022 (2022-06-12) (Tribeca)
March 31, 2023 (2023-03-31) (United States)
Running time92 minutesCountryUnited StatesLanguageEnglish
Space Oddity is a 2022 American romantic comedy science fiction film directed by Kyra Sedgwick and written by Rebecca Banner. It stars Kyle Allen, Alexandra Shipp, Madeline Brewer, Carrie Preston, Simon Helberg and Kevin Bacon.


Premise[edit]
A man tries to secure insurance in order to go on a one-way trip to Mars but falls in love.

Cast[edit]
Kyle Allen as Alex McAllister
Alexandra Shipp as Daisy Taylor
Madeline Brewer as Liz
Kevin Bacon as Jeff McAllister
Simon Helberg as Dmitri
Carrie Preston as Jane McAllister
Arden Myrin as Lisa
Production[edit]
It was announced in June 2021 that Kyra Sedgwick would direct the film, written by Rebecca Banner, with Kyle Allen, Alexandra Shipp and Madeline Brewer set to star.[1] In July, Kevin Bacon, Simon Helberg and Carrie Preston were added to the cast.[2]
Filming began in June 2021, with production taking place throughout Rhode Island.[3][4]

Release[edit]
The film had its premiere at the 2022 Tribeca Film Festival on June 12, 2022.[5] It was released by Samuel Goldwyn Films on March 31, 2023.[6]

Reception[edit]
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 56% of 27 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 6.2/10.[7] Manuel Betancourt of Variety wrote, "If the film never quite finds a way to marry its high concept premise, its twee romance, and its family melodrama into one cohesive narrative, it is not for lack of trying."[8] Robert Abele of TheWrap wrote, "That’s a compelling set-up for a knotty family story, but not as evidenced by the surface cutes that keep real feeling at bay in this curiously uninvolving directorial effort from Kyra Sedgwick."[9] In a positive review, Brian Orndorf of Blu-ray.com wrote, "[The film] isn’t an overly cinematic viewing experience, but it has deep feeling for its characters and an unusual approach to the trials of grief, going in compelling directions as the whole thing works hard to avoid becoming a melodrama."[10]

^ Pugliese, Laura (June 28, 2021). "New movie filming in R.I. called Space Oddity hopes to spark local economy". WLNE-TV. Retrieved August 3, 2022.

^ Noori Farzan, Antonia (August 8, 2021). "Saunderstown's Robin Hollow Farm takes star turn in upcoming film directed by Kyra Sedgwick". The Providence Journal. Retrieved August 3, 2022.

^ Goldsmith, Jill (April 19, 2022). "Tribeca Festival Lineup Includes Corner Office With Jon Hamm, Ray Romano's Somewhere In Queens, More". Deadline Hollywood. Retrieved August 3, 2022.

^ Valle, Ali (February 12, 2023). "Space Oddity Drops Official Trailer Ahead of March Premiere". MovieWeb. Retrieved February 22, 2023.

^ "Space Oddity". Rotten Tomatoes. Fandango Media. Retrieved July 9, 2023. 

^ Betancourt, Manuel (June 13, 2022). "'Space Oddity' Review: A Trip to Mars and a Sweet Romance Anchor This All-Too-Sweet Drama". Variety. Retrieved July 9, 2023.

^ Abele, Robert (June 12, 2022). "Space Oddity Film Review: Family Drama About a Cosmos-Obsessed Son Never Lifts Off". TheWrap. Retrieved July 9, 2023.

^ Orndorf, Brian (March 29, 2023). "Space Oddity (2022)". Blu-ray.com. Retrieved July 9, 2023.
